lexUnit.name: stand up.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: assume a standing position, typically from lying or sitting

sentence.text: The next day , he got up , sat in the sun , stood up , and fainted so completely I thought he was dead .
Stanley stood up awkwardly .
He stood up and went out on to the landing .
After a while the man stood up .
She grabbed the receiver while Nina stood up , anticipating trouble , and watching Rachel as she took the call .
The older woman stood up quickly , cake crumbs falling to the carpet , and faced Juliet .
` Right , sir , " Doone said , as I stood up out of the car , ` we 've done nothing here so far .
When the superintendent stood up she saw Wootton standing a few yards away .
When he stood up he could just see a fire engine as if on the high seas diving and heaving towards him .
As she stood up she caught sight of her reflection in the fly-spotted mirror .
He stood up .
He stood up slowly and entered the lounge .
Steiner stood up .
This is for a straight lecture , you know sometimes people stand up to give you a lecture .
They stood up and Bobbie took the stub of the torch .
It was n't until Ronni stood up at the shore 's edge that she saw Guido standing watching her , bare feet planted in the sand .
The two men stood up and said goodbye .
Herr Nordern stood up rather stiffly and squared his shoulders .
And she stood up as the song ended , clapping with all her might .
Menzies stood up very straight and arranged his clothes .
The Inspector stood up very tall and straight in his fine uniform .
I stand up in the entrance of my bower , still in shadow .
Mr Wishart stood up and opened it for her , handing her the wicker basket which seemed surprisingly light ; the old lady stepped off the train onto a now deserted platform .
Rossi had already stood up to join in the sport .
Horowitz replaced the phone , stood up slowly without a word , walked slowly up to the guard .
` Please stand up and recite as much of it as you can . "
Get fit , get slim , practise standing up straight with your hands behind your back ( a sign of confidence ) .
